children.text: Systems design questions are coming up more and more in software development interviews - it's a much more technical interview question, more so than an algorithmic interview, because it actually is rooted in real-world circumstances.

For example, what if you were asked in an interview to design Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or some other network for billions of users - what are the considerations? I will add a different example later, but from now enjoy this overview from geeksforgeeks.org:
You need to design a social media service for billions of users. Most of the interviewer spend time in the discussion of news feed generation service in these apps.
Features to be considered:
Some of the specific Twitter/Facebook/Instagram features to be supported.
Privacy controls around each tweet or post.
User should be able to post tweets also the system should support replies to tweets/grouping tweets by conversations.
User should be able to see trending tweets/post.
Direct messaging
Mentions/Tagging.
User should be able to follow another user.
Things to analyze:
System should be able to handle the huge amount of traffic for billions of users.
Number of followers
Number of times the tweet has been favorited.
Components:
News feed generation.
Social graph (Friend connection networking between users or who follows whom?—?specially when millions of users are following a celebrity)
Efficient storage and search for posts or tweets.

The point is, they are testing your ability to think through edge cases and a more comprehensive view of the system you are designing. They don't want a casual answer - they want you to go in depth how you would handle scaling a service, how to efficiently query millions of items in databases, social graphs, etc.
Don't be too discouraged - these are hard questions, but become infinitely easier to answer with experience.

sanityInterview.title: Systems Design Interviewing Questions

children.text: Para su revisión, por favor escriba una respuesta de un párrafo para cada una de las preguntas de la hoja de entrevistas de Pareto.
For review, please write out a one paragraph answer for every one of the questions on the Pareto Interviewing sheet.

Para la aceptación, programa una entrevista con tu entrenador o conocido profesional - y revisa el rendimiento + sube a YouTube, para que puedas ver tu lenguaje corporal y que tu entrenador pueda revisarlo también.

For acceptance, schedule an interview with your coach or professional acquaintance - and review the performance + upload to YouTube, so that you can watch your body language and that your coach can review it as well.

Para la aceptación, programa una entrevista con tu entrenador o conocido profesional - y revisa el rendimiento + sube a YouTube, para que puedas ver tu lenguaje corporal y que tu entrenador pueda revisarlo también.

For acceptance, schedule an interview with your coach or professional acquaintance - and review the performance + upload to YouTube, so that you can watch your body language and that your coach can review it as well.

En tu kit de inicio de Pareto se incluye un cuaderno de ejercicios de ideas, un conjunto de ejercicios que completarás por ti mismo, o preferiblemente con tu entrenador. Hay un número de buenos ejercicios:- Hacer una larga lluvia de ideas sobre las oportunidades disponibles para ti en base a tu experiencia laboral pasada, tu familia, tus amigos, tu ciudad particular, un conjunto de hobbies, etcétera. El punto es que el proyecto debe estar relacionado con algo único en ti.- Una vez que te hayas decidido por las dos ideas principales, es el momento de pensar en el caso de los negocios - ¿por qué vale la pena este software para alguien? ¿Cómo les ayuda? ¿Hay algún modelo de negocio que valga la pena explorar? Si no lo hay, ¿cómo puede este software ser útil a la sociedad o a sus amigos y familiares?- Una vez que haya pensado en esas piezas de software, ahora es el momento de hacer algunos prototipos ligeros. Te haremos esbozar imágenes de cómo podría ser la interfaz de usuario, en una dimensión de móvil, tableta y escritorio.- Ahora es el momento de pensar en los datos - ¿qué tipo de información necesito para ser capaz de almacenar y modificar, con el fin de añadir valor a los usuarios? Guardar sus nombres y simple información personal es un buen comienzo, pero ¿qué otra información y lógica de negocios sería útil para las personas para las que su software está diseñado?Para su revisión, suba las fotos de cada una de las páginas como archivos a un repositorio github y envíe el enlace para su revisión. Eso, o las imágenes pueden ser revisadas a través de una videollamada.

Included in your Pareto Starter kit is an Ideation workbook - a set of exercises that you will complete either by yourself, or preferably with your coach. There are a number of good excercises:- Doing an extended brainstorm about what opportunities are available for you based on your past work experience, family, friends, your particular city, a set of hobbies, etcetera. The point is that the project should be related to something uniquely you.- Once you've settled on the top two ideas, it's time to think through the business case - why is this piece of software worth someones time? How does it help them? Is there a business model worth exploring? If not, how can this piece of software be helpful to society or to your friends and family?- Once you have thought through those pieces of software, now is the time to do some light prototyping. We will have you sketch out pictures of what the user interface might look like, on a mobile, tablet and desktop dimension.- Now it's time to think through the data - what kind of information do I need to be able to store and modify, in order to add value to the users? Saving their names and simple personal information is a good start, but what other information and business logic would be helpful the the people your software is designed for?For review, upload pictures of each of the pages as files into a github repository and send the link for review. Either that, or pictures can be reviewed over video call.

Lo crea o no, no necesita construir todo completamente desde cero al comenzar un nuevo proyecto. Puede tomar un 'kit de inicio', a menudo llamado plantilla, o plantillas, y comenzar su proyecto basado en React con una base sólida. La mayoría de las veces, no necesita demasiado: lo mejor es un buen CSS básico y un par de componentes de inicio bien elaborados con el esquema de color correcto.

Si tiene problemas para seleccionar el modelo estándar, puede seguir adelante y utilizar el modelo estándar del tutorial de Serverless Stack. Vuelva a hacer el tutorial y cambie algunas cosas de 'notas' a 'productos' o 'barras' o 'perros' o lo que sea que gire su producto.

Puede encontrar una gran cantidad de texto estándar en GitHub; tenga en cuenta que el texto estándar debe centrarse en la función. Debería ser relativamente simple, a menos que sepa lo que está haciendo. Por diversión, siga adelante y clone este repositorio en su computadora y revise el código. Así es como se ve un texto estándar muy maduro. ¿Lo necesitas todo? No ahora, tal vez en el futuro pueda funcionar para usted. Por ahora, elija algo que sea simple, fácil de aprender y comience.

sanityProduct.esTitle: Elegir plantilla de código para producto

children.text: Believe it or not, you do not need to build everything completely from scratch when starting a new project. You can take a 'starter-kit', often called boilerplate, or templates, and start your React-based project with a solid foundation. Most of the time, you don't need too much - some good, foundational CSS and a couple of well-crafted starter components with the right color scheme are best.

If you are having trouble selecting boilerplate, you can go ahead and use the boilerplate from the Serverless Stack tutorial. Re-do the tutorial and change some things from 'notes' to 'products' or 'bars' or 'dogs' or whatever your product revolves around.

You are able to find lots of boilerplate on GitHub - keep in mind that the boilerplate should be focused on function. It should be relatively simple, unless you know what you are doing. For kicks, go ahead and
clone this repository

to your computer and walk through the code. That is what very mature boilerplate looks like. Do you need all of it? Not right now - maybe in the future it can work for you. For now, pick something that's simple, easy to pick up and get started with.

sanityProduct.title: Choose Boilerplate for Product

children.text: Antes de comenzar a escribir código, muchas veces es mejor visualizar lo que desea. Ahí es donde entran en juego los ejercicios de estructura de alambre incluidos en el libro de trabajo Ideación: ya ha realizado una ronda de estructura de alambre y prototipos de las pantallas más importantes.

Ahora, vamos a hacer una segunda ronda de wireframing para esas mismas pantallas, esta vez, trate de obtener más detalles, ¡y no solo en papel! Esta vez, usaremos un software gratuito de UX Design llamado Adobe XD (u opciones pagas Sketch / Figma) para armar maquetas simples de esas pantallas.

Buscará en Google 'Paquetes de inicio de Sketch' y encontrará muchas respuestas: muchos diseñadores gráficos cargan plantillas gratuitas con las que puede trabajar. Allí encontrará mucha inspiración para el diseño de interfaces, además de hacerse una idea del aspecto que pueden tener las aplicaciones modernas. Descarga varios (10) y revísalos, seleccionando las partes que te gustan y que luego se combinarán en una maqueta "real" de las interfaces que dibujaste.

A lo largo del proceso, es posible que se dé cuenta de que la idea que tenía en su cabeza se veía mejor ... en su cabeza. ¡Y eso está totalmente bien! Mejore el diseño y, cuando crea que tiene listas las pantallas para la funcionalidad más importante, programe una reunión de 30 minutos con usted y su entrenador para revisarlas juntos.

sanityProduct.esTitle: Marcos de Alambre + Diseño de la Interfaz de Usuario

children.text: Before you start writing code, it's often-times better to visualize what you want. That's where the wire-framing excercises included in the Ideation workbook come in - you have already done one round of wireframing and prototyping the most important screens.

Now, we are going to do a second round of wireframing  for those sames screens - this time, try to eke out more details - and not just on paper! This time, we will be using some free UX Design software called Adobe XD (or paid options Sketch / Figma) to put together simple mockups of those screens.

You will Google for 'Sketch starter packs' and find many answers - a lot of graphic designers upload free templates that you can work from. You will find a lot of inspiration for interface design there, as well as get an idea of what modern applications may look like. Download multiple (10) and look through them, picking out the parts you like that will then be combined together into a 'real' mockup of the interfaces that you sketched out.

Along the process, you might realize that the idea you had in your head looked better... in your head. And, that's totally fine! Improve the design, and when you think you have the screens for the most important functionality ready, then schedule a 30 minute meeting with you and your coach to review them together!

sanityProduct.title: Wireframes + UI Design w/ Adobe XD

children.text: Una de las claves del éxito como ingeniero de software profesional es dejar una documentación completa y útil. Hay una serie de cosas que hay que considerar:
Incorporar a los nuevos desarrolladores al entorno de desarrollo
Directrices para nombrar las ramas de git
Requisitos de la solicitud de extracción
Información general sobre las capacidades y funcionalidad de la aplicación dentro del repositorio.
Orientación sobre variables de entorno, entorno (prod/dev), etc.
Para su revisión, por favor deje instrucciones completas que pueda seguir con éxito, sin errores, para que la aplicación se ejecute con éxito en mi entorno local.

Volviendo al tema de la documentación, un documento de Swagger es una guía de la API que tiene como objetivo ayudar a los miembros del equipo a comprender instantáneamente los atributos necesarios para completar con éxito una solicitud de la API. Además de ayudarte a especificar los tipos de atributos y todas las rutas de API disponibles, también generará automáticamente un conjunto de pruebas con Mocha & Chai para aumentar la cobertura de las pruebas de la interfaz.

¿Por qué es esto importante? Aparte del hecho de que muchos equipos utilizan este tipo de documentación, es importante recordar que la mayoría de los equipos de desarrollo de software no operan en pequeños silos, construyendo aplicaciones al estilo del lobo solitario. Muchos de ellos trabajan en equipo, y a veces necesitan exponer sus API, para que un equipo, o cliente, o socio estratégico pueda integrar esos datos con los suyos.
Un documento de pavoneo es la manera perfecta de demostrar que entiendes la importancia de la documentación, y puedes incluirlo en tu currículum.

sanityProduct.esTitle: Documentación de incorporación + Especificación de API abierta

children.text: One of the keys to success as a professional software engineer is to leave thorough and helpful documentation. There are a number of things to consider:
Onboarding new developers into the dev environment
Guidelines for naming git branches
Pull-request requirements
General information about the capabilities & functionality of the application inside the repository.
Guidance involving environment variables, environment (prod/dev), etc.
For review, please leave full-onboarding instructions that I can successfully follow, without error, to have the application successfully running in my local environment.

Coming back to the topic of documentation, a Swagger document is an API guide that is meant to help team members instantly understand the required attributes needed to successfully complete an API request. In addition to helping you specify attribute types and all the available API routes, it will also auto-generate a test suite with Mocha & Chai to raise your backend test coverage.

Why is this important? Aside from the fact that many teams use this type of documentation, it's important to remember that most software development teams are not operating in small silos, building out applications lone-wolf style. A lot of them are working in teams, and sometimes they need to expose their API's, so that a team, or client, or strategic partner can integrate that data with yours.
A Swagger document is the perfect way to demonstrate that you understand the importance of documentation, and you can include it on your resume.

sanityProduct.title: Onboarding Documentation + Open API Specification

children.text: Para construir su MVP de pila completa, tendrá dos características que brindan el valor adecuado para que la aplicación sea un producto viable. Para la primera característica, antes de implementar una solución de base de datos, nos centraremos en desarrollar el código de front-end utilizando únicamente datos simulados. Esto se puede hacer con objetos `useState` que se actualizan al usar formularios y al recibir datos de una API simulada. Una vez que tengamos los datos finales simulados que son necesarios para los componentes, es cuando armaremos la base de datos final, y en ese punto, integrar la base de datos será tan simple como escribir las consultas / estructurar el cuerpo de la solicitud, enviarlo y recibiendo el estado actualizado para mostrar en el front-end.

Para su revisión, por favor envíe el enlace a la rama de su repositorio GitHub que tiene el código que le gustaría revisar. Tu entrenador probablemente enviará una solicitud de extracción con recomendaciones, y pedirá que se hagan las revisiones. Una vez que se hayan hecho las revisiones, vuelve a enviar aquí para ganar tu EXP.

For building out your full-stack MVP, you will have two features that provide the proper value for the application to be a viable product. For the first feature, before we implement a database solution, we are going to focus on building out the front-end code purely using mock data. This can be done by have `useState` objects that refresh when using forms, and when receiving data back from a mock API. Once we have the final mock data thats necessary for the components, that is when we will put together the final database - and at that point, integrating the database will be as simple as writing the queries/structuring the request body, sending it over and receiving the updated state to show in the front-end.

For review, please send the link to the branch of your GitHub repository that has the code you would like to review. Your coach will likely send a pull-request with commends, and ask for revisions made. Once revisions have been made, resubmit here to earn your EXP.
Una de las tareas más fáciles, implementar el sistema de autenticación que usará para rastrear a sus usuarios. Esto implica tres cosas:
1. Crear el backend de Cognito, ya sea a través de aws-cli o a través del tablero de Cognito, que almacenará la información de autenticación de tus usuarios.
2. Creando los formularios en su front-end para registrar e iniciar la sesión de esos usuarios.
3. Crear una vista 'autenticada' y 'no autenticada' en tu aplicación, con el React Router bloqueando el acceso a las Rutas que requieren autenticación si no estás autenticado.
4. Para la revisión, envíe la solicitud de extracción con el trabajo que hay dentro de ella.
One of the easier tasks, implementing the Authentication system you will use to track your users. This involves three things:
1. Creating the Cognito backend, either through the aws-cli or through Cognito dashboard, which will store the authentication information for your users.
2. Creating the forms in your front-end to register and login those users.
3. Create an 'authenticated' and 'inauthenticated' view in your application, with React Router blocking access to Routes that require authentication if you are unauthenticated.
For review, send the pull-request with those work inside of it.

Después de crear los componentes estáticos para la función principal, la integración del back-end será relativamente simple. Hay tres partes: el objeto JavaScript que contiene los datos que queremos guardar / modificar, la API y la base de datos.

Al guardar o actualizar cualquier información, enviaremos una solicitud HTTP POST o PUT a nuestra API sin servidor Node.js. Incluiremos un objeto JavaScript como el 'cuerpo' del evento, lo que significa que es la carga útil principal. La biblioteca 'API' de AWS-Amplify convertirá automáticamente el objeto JavaScript a JSON, que es una cadena en forma de objeto JavaScript.

Dentro de la función Node, deberá convertir esa cadena JSON de nuevo en un objeto JS utilizando la API `JSON.parse (obj)`. Luego, ejecutará alguna lógica comercial, tal vez actualizará una base de datos, interactuará con una API de terceros y luego devolverá algunos datos al front-end. Con AWS Lambda, deberá devolver un código de estado de 200, así como un 'cuerpo de respuesta' que podría, por ejemplo, incluir un objeto de base de datos actualizado que el front-end recibirá y puede usar para actualizar el 'estado' de la aplicación con los datos más recientes.

Para su revisión, envíe el enlace a la rama de su repositorio de GitHub que tiene el código que le gustaría revisar. Es probable que su entrenador envíe una solicitud de extracción con elogios y solicite las revisiones realizadas. Una vez que se hayan realizado las revisiones, vuelva a enviarlas aquí para obtener su EXP.

After creating the static components for the main feature, integrating the back-end is going to be relatively simple. There are three parts - the JavaScript object containing the data we want to save/modify, the API, and the database.

When saving or updating any information, we will be sending a POST or PUT http request to our Node.js serverless API. We will be including a JavaScript object as the 'body' of the event, meaning that its the primary payload. The AWS-Amplify 'API' library will automatically convert the JavaScript object to JSON, which is a string in the form of a JavaScript object.

Inside the Node function, you will need to convert that JSON string back to a JS object using the `JSON.parse(obj)` API. You will then run through some business logic, perhaps update a database, interact with a third-party API, and then return some data to the front-end. Will AWS Lambda, you will need to return a status code of 200, as well as a 'response body' that could, for example, include an updated database object that the front-end will receive and can use to refresh the 'state' of the application with the newest data.

For review, please send the link to the branch of your GitHub repository that has the code you would like to review. Your coach will likely send a pull-request with commends, and ask for revisions made. Once revisions have been made, resubmit here to earn your EXP.

En un equipo de desarrollo bien engrasado, puedes estar empujando a las ramas de desarrollo y producción varias veces al día. Por ello, es importante tener un flujo de integración continuo que automatice todo el proceso, mientras se minimizan los riesgos de fallos críticos. Algunas de las facetas útiles de una integración de IC:

Importación de variables del entorno de desarrollo/producción en el proceso de construcción de la aplicación, antes de su despliegue automatizado en su servicio sin servidor, contenedor Docker, cubo S3, etc.
Ser capaz de ejecutar a través de su conjunto de pruebas de dev/prod, antes del despliegue y capaz de identificar los posibles problemas antes de enviar el código roto.

Ahorro de tiempo, al no tener que ejecutar manualmente los scripts necesarios para el despliegue, especialmente si no tiene acceso inmediato a claves privadas como credenciales de bases de datos, secretos de API, etc.

Podrá desplegar sin problemas su aplicación React a través de la Consola de Amplificación AWS - simplemente conecte una rama de GitHub, enlácela a un dominio de su propiedad a través de Route53, y ¡listo!
Para su revisión, por favor, envíe un enlace al prod link para su punto final de despliegue de integración continua.

On a well-oiled development team, you may be pushing to the development and production branches multiple times a day. As such, it's important to have a continous integration flow that automates that entire process, while minimizing the risks of critical failure. Some of the useful facets of a CI integration:
Importing development/production environment variables into the application build process, prior to automated deployment to your serverless service, Docker container, S3 bucket, etc.
Being able to run through your dev/prod test suite, prior to deployment & able to identify potential issues before shipping broken code.
Saving time, not having to manually run the  scripts necessary for deployment, especially if you do not have immediate access to private keys such as database credentials, API secrets, etc.
You will be able to seamlessly deploy your React application through the AWS Amplify Console - simply connect a branch from GitHub, link it to a domain you own through Route53, and presto!
For review, please send a link to the prod link for your continous integration deployment endpoint.

La seguridad es una de esas cosas en las que muchos desarrolladores, especialmente los jóvenes, no piensan mucho. Después de todo, ¿quién podría querer robar la información personal de mi pequeña aplicación?
Bueno, estoy aquí para decirte que es un mal hábito que se debe formar - deberías pensar proactivamente en la privacidad de tu usuario y en salvaguardar su información.
Hay algunas cosas que hay que tener en cuenta:
Inyección SQL (si es aplicable)
Ataques de la escritura cruzada (XSS)
Asegurando sus API's con tokens JWT

Cuando se presenta información técnica densa a los clientes, compañeros de equipo, ejecutivos o interesados de cualquier tipo, es fundamental poder presentar esa información de manera sencilla y eficaz. Una de las mejores maneras de hacerlo es a través de ayudas visuales - usted ganará experiencia en este esfuerzo elaborando un diagrama de arquitectura usando la herramienta (en su mayoría) gratuita LucidCharts e incluirlo en su documentación.

Es probable que la arquitectura de su aplicación no sea muy compleja - tiene un front-end, que recibe la autenticación a través de AWS Cognito, y luego envía las solicitudes de API a un servicio sin servidor, que luego consulta la base de datos para los datos que se envían todo el camino de vuelta al front-end.

Elaborar un diagrama arquitectónico utilizando las Cartas Lúcidas será un gran ejercicio para ayudarte a pensar en cómo se ven estos diseños arquitectónicos en papel, y será una gran guía que puedes incluir en el sitio web de tu portafolio/donde sea que estés anunciando tus habilidades.

Para la revisión, por favor envíe un PDF/imagen del diagrama de arquitectura - asegúrese de que las flechas en las solicitudes documenten el flujo de datos en ambos sentidos desde el front-end, a la api, a la base de datos y viceversa.
Para su revisión, debe reunirse con su entrenador para identificar los agujeros abiertos - luego enviar una solicitud de extracción que muestre el trabajo completado.

sanityProduct.esTitle: Auditoría de seguridad + Diagram de arqitectura

children.text: Security is one of those things that a lot of developers, especially junior developers, don't think too much about. After all, who could possible want to steal my little app's personally identifiable information?
Well, I'm here to tell you that's a bad habit to form - you should be proactively thinking about your user's privacy and safeguarding their information.
There are a few things to keep in mind:
SQL Injection (if applicable)
Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Attacks
Securing your API's with JWT Tokens

When presenting dense technical information to clients, teammates, executives, or stakeholders of any kind, it is critical to be able to present that information simply and effectively. One of the best ways to do so is through visual aids - you will gain experience in this endeavor by drawing up an architecture diagram using the (mostly) free tool LucidCharts & include it in your documentation.

Your application architecture is likely not very complex - you have a front-end, which receives authentication through AWS Cognito, and then sends API requests to a serverless serice, which then queries the database for data that is sent all the way back to the front-end.

Drawing up an architectural diagram using Lucid Charts will be a great excercise to help you think about how these architectural designs look on paper, and will be a great guide that you can include on your portfolio website/wherever you are advertising your skills.
For review, please submit a PDF/image of the architecture diagram - make sure the arrows on the requests document the two way dataflow from the front-end, to api, to database, and back.
For review, you must meet with your coach to identify the gaping holes - then send a pull-request showing the completed work.

sanityProduct.title: Security Audit + Architecture Diagram

children.text: La optimización de los motores de búsqueda es el arte y la ciencia de asegurarse de que su sitio web sea tan fácilmente accesible a través de los motores de búsqueda como sea humanamente posible. Idealmente, son el primer resultado "orgánico" que se ve en la primera página de Google.

Lo que queremos hacer es asegurarnos de que nuestra aplicación tenga un SEO decente. Esto implicará el establecimiento de algunos meta-tags dentro de nuestro index.html y el uso de una biblioteca llamada "Casco de Reacción" - una forma de añadir metadatos HTML personalizados dentro de los componentes de React que son el principal contenedor de una Ruta a través de un Router de Reacción.
Trabaja con las sugerencias de esta página, más específicamente para pensar en la elección de palabras clave en tus metadatos HTML.
Implemente la biblioteca npm "React-Helmet" dentro de su aplicación React (suponiendo que sea web, no móvil) y añada meta-información personalizada para cada Ruta en el React-Router.
Para su revisión, por favor envíe la solicitud de extracción que contiene los cambios realizados para este logro.

sanityProduct.esTitle: Optimización de los motores de búsqueda

children.text: Search engine optimization is the art and science of making sure that your website is as easily accessible through search engines as humanly possible. Ideally, they are the first 'organic' result that you see on the front page of Google.

What we will want to do is to make sure that our application has decent SEO. This will involve setting some meta-tags inside of our index.html & using a library called 'React Helmet' - a way of adding custom HTML metadata inside of React components that are the main container for a Route through React Router.
Work through the suggestions
in this page
​, more specifically to think through the choice of keywords in your HTML meta-data.
Implement 'React-Helmet' npm library inside of your React application (assuming its web, not mobile) and add custom meta-information for each Route in React-Router.
For review, please send the pull-request that contains the changes made for this Achievement.

sanityProduct.title: Search Engine Optimization

children.text: Una vez que tu MVP esté listo para ser usado, es hora de encontrar algunos usuarios. Mientras los encuentras, mira cómo usan el producto, o usa un servicio como LogRocket para grabar toda su sesión de usuario.

El punto es recoger los comentarios y si están o no usando la aplicación de una manera que les ayude. Si no entienden cómo usarla, entonces no les está ayudando. Si lo entienden, pero no les ayuda - puede que no sean su público objetivo o que tengan algunas suposiciones erróneas sobre lo que necesitan.

Lo que quieres hacer es hacer una auditoría de la Experiencia de Usuario una vez que hayas hecho que 5 personas que coincidan con tu persona ideal la usen. Toma los comentarios de las 5, o sólo de una, y utilízalos para crear más elementos para el producto que se ha retrasado en la iteración de la aplicación hacia lo que se llama "Producto apto para el mercado".
Para su revisión, envíe un enlace a un documento de Google que resuma sus hallazgos después de esta auditoría.

sanityProduct.esTitle: Auditoría de la Experiencia del Usuario

children.text: Once your MVP is ready for use, it's time to find some users. As you find them, watch how they use the product, or use a service like LogRocket to record their entire user sesssion.

The point is to collect feedback and whether or not they are using the application in a way that is helping them. If they do not understand how to use it, then it's not helping them. If they do understand it, but it doesn't help them - they might not be your target audience or you have some mistaken assumptions about what they need.

What you want to do is to have an audit of the User Experience once you've had 5 people who match your ideal persona use it. Take the feedback from all 5, or just one, and use it to create more items for the product backlog towards iterating the application towards what's called 'Product Market Fit'.
For review, please submit a link to a Google document summarizing your findings after this audit.

sanityProduct.title: Guerrilla UX: User Experience Audit

children.text: Después de completar su investigación de usuarios y observar los problemas que tenían sus usuarios, es hora de abordar los comentarios de los usuarios y mejorar el software de manera tangible. El primer paso es observar cuidadosamente cómo lo usan y dónde ve una posible desconexión. Si tienen problemas para encontrar algo importante o no comprenden lo que se supone que deben hacer, ese es un indicador útil para que lo revise.

También es posible que, mientras los observa usar el software, observe algunas deficiencias obvias en la interfaz que no fueron necesariamente obvias para usted mientras las desarrollaba. Recuerde que el software es como su hijo: puede pensar que son mejores y más geniales que ellos, y es posible que no note algo hasta que lo ponga al lado de otro niño y observe cómo se comparan. Mientras observa a los usuarios, debe tomar notas increíblemente detalladas.

El segundo paso es convertir todos esos problemas en 'tickets', que luego organizará en su tablero de Proyecto en GitHub. Luego, usted y su entrenador los organizarán en orden de importancia y realizarán una reunión de planificación de sprints para estimar la cantidad de trabajo que se puede realizar en el transcurso de un sprint de dos semanas.
El tercer paso es ejecutar sin descanso, terminar los elementos y recorrer una retrospectiva con su entrenador.

After completing your User Research, and observing the hang-ups that your users had, it's time to address that user feedback and improve the software in tangible ways. The first step is to carefully watch how they use it, and where you see a potential disconnect. If they are having trouble finding something important, or not understanding what they are supposed to do, that's a helpful indicator for you to review.

You might also, while watching them use the software, notice some obvious deficiencies in the interface that were not necessarily obvious to you while developing them. Remember that software is like your child - you might think they are better and cooler than they are, and might not notice something until you put them next to another kid and notice how they compare. While watching the users, you need to be taking incredibly detailed notes.

The second step is to convert all of those issues into 'tickets', which you will then organize on your Project board on GitHub. You and your coach will then organize them in order of important, and run a sprint planning meeting to estimate the amount of work able to be done over the course of a two-week sprint.
The third step is to relentlessly execute, finish the items and walk through a retrospective with your coach.

¡Felicidades por construir su Producto Mínimo Viable (MVP)! Pendiente de revisión, la parte más difícil de su viaje de aprendizaje ha terminado - ahora tiene un artículo de la marquesina en su portafolio, ¡y avanza con confianza!

Congrats on building your Minimum Viable Product (MVP)! Pending review, the hardest part of your learning journey is over - you now have a marquee item on your portfolio, and come move forward with confidence!

You’re probably wondering what to do with all the data your users enter, or where to get the information you want to display to them. This is where the “back-end”, or server, stores and processes all the business logic and data data access that happens to support your user experience.

The back-end traditionally consisted of a server, running code that would respond to HTTP requests for data at certain “routes”. Each section of your application, or resource, might have its own set of actions users can perform. For example, if you’re trying to build a doggy daycare management system, you’d need to store info about pets, owners, and doggy-sitters. Each of these would be considered its own resource, where users could Create, Read, Update, and Delete records. These four operations are commonly abbreviated as CRUD, and are the connective tissue of most applications. One can query their data store directly, or create a system of business logic encapsulated in what are called ‘controller functions’ - routes in your back-end system that, when hit by a specific HTTP methods, trigger a specific piece of functionality.

For a long time in the industry, monolithic servers were the only game in town. These were large, consolidated code-bases that grew to be highly optimized & resistant to overload, but were painful to update - especially if one team at a company “owned” part of the code, that another team wanted to modify.

Partly a reaction to that, and partly in response to the continued advance of Moore’s law, microservices entered vogue in the first half of the 2010’s. These were isolated software containers, which accomplished a few key pieces of business functionality while being separate from the rest of the application unless they were directly tied together. This had certain performance and security benefits, but also proved to be difficult to scale as a ‘web’ of microservices could prove difficult to handle, especially on teams that do not keep reliable documentation or reasonable testing suites.

Serverless is the latest item in the trend, though massively simpler than containerized microservices. Think of a serverless function as just that - a pure function that spins up a container, executes its specified operation, and spins back down. No need to pay for a containerized microservice, or monolithic REST API to monitor endpoints continously - simply fire, and forget. Backed by the reliability of AWS - it’s worth that your first million invocations (calls) each month are FREE!

Monolithic REST API’s have their place - there are many benefits to having overlapping functionality held in the same repo, and depending on what packages and dependencies you are using - it might be a lot better for performance to host a containerized monolith as opposed to a full serverless stack. Balance, as in all things, is key. Ideology should give way to pragmatism.

technicalSchemas.description: We recommend a serverless-first approach to back-end development - great for firing large volume, asynchronous requests that work with data.
technicalSchemas.title: Serverless

children.text: Front-end development refers to the code that creates the client experience - the interface that your users will interact with. Even though we are taking the ‘Full-Stack JavaScript’ approach, this doesn’t immediately help us pick out which framework to use. Search online, and you will find fierce debates between React, Vue, Angular & a variety of smaller, less popular solutions. JQuery, released in 2006, is still deployed in production across wide swathes of the internet. WordPress is huge.

FSA recommends React Web & Native for your front-end development needs, for a couple of very good reasons. The first being the emergence of React Native - by abstracting away some pieces of your application to a library like Redux, it allows you to re-use 75% of the code-base across your web and mobile applications. Not to mention, your React Native application almost automatically creates the Android & iOS application! This means that you don’t need to have 3 difference code-bases to manage your platform - you just need 2, which re-use 75% of the code between themselves. No need to learn iOS (Swift/Objective-C) or Android (Java/Kotlin/Flutter) development - build everything using JavaScript & React. Scaling your features, and maintaining parity between all 3 of your platforms will be much easier.

What are the differences between React and Vue/Angular? Those two options do not offer a comparable Native application solution, and even when they do (Vue is getting there, slowly!) the community support will pale in comparison. React is maintained by Facebook, Vue.js is maintained by (mostly) one open-source developer. The number of open-source components, modules and reference materials will never add up to the same level.

Now, if your local job market has an obsession with Angular, perhaps its in your best interest to learn that. Always remember that ideology should give way to pragmatism - the FSA Technical Standard is there to provide a ‘default’ option for those learning development, but that does not mean it is a one-size fits all panacea.

As you spend time building your first marquee application, and developing the React web application, you will want to then migrate that application to React-Native to have a dynamic, cross-platform experience. When doing this, you will migrate the state management of the application to Redux if you have not already - by doing that, you will be able to re-use a large chunk of your code base and build experience developing a production ready application.

technicalSchemas.description: It started with the web, but it spread to mobile phones - React is the most effective way of creating digital experiences in 2019.
technicalSchemas.title: React.js

children.text: If you do not consider the needs of the user, before everything else, your application, product or service will be a failure. As a developer, you live to serve your users. If you keep hearing feedback such as ‘I can’t quite figure it out’, it doesn’t mean they ‘are stupid’ or ‘don’t get it’ or ‘too old’ - it means that you designed a piece of software that nobody can figure out how to use. You shouldn’t need text on the screen to instruct the user what to do next. It is your fault, not theirs.

If you want users to genuinely engage with your product, and to tell their friends about it, you need to create the product of their dreams. That involves researching exactly what they want, as well as learning about how human psychology affects the way we interact with technology. Some call this field of study ‘Human Centered Design’ or ‘Human Computer Interaction’ (HCI).

As a Full-Stack Apprentice, you are not a UX Designer - that is a field that demands its own practitioners & experts. However, it is a hard and fast requirement that you understand the principles of great design & human psychology so that when you work with a UX Designer, your relationship can be productive and profitable. The designer, and developer for that matter, should understand - is there actually a problem here to solve? How would we actually solve the problem, as opposed to missing the mark?

From a user-experience perspective, the entire solution should be intuitive - as if it should have been there from the start.  You could have the most brilliant, innovative product in the world but it means nothing if users can’t figure out how to use it. If it looks so ugly that it repulses them before they can even give it a chance, you’re shooting yourself in the foot.

One of the core jobs of UX designers is to facilitate the right design cues in the application, from the color scheme, button layout & general application design. The developer provides the implementation, though the UX designer should be able to contribute CSS & HTML (ideally within React) to enhance the styling, look & feel of the application. Their core responsibility, outside of UI and interface design, is to be the mouth of the user - to understand what they need, and how to properly solve their problems.

Jakob Nielsen developed 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design in 1995, and they are still relevant today. I’ve included them below, and you can find dedicated articles regarding each of them on the site here.
Visibility of System Status
Match between system and the real world
User control and freedom
Consistency and standards
Error prevention
Recognition rather than recall
Flexibility and efficiency of use
Aesthetic and minimalist design
Help users recognize, diagnose and recover from errors
Help and documentation

technicalSchemas.description: There is no excuse for bad design.
technicalSchemas.title: User Experience (UX) Design

children.text: FSA TS Recommends: Cypress for pretty much all of your testing needs, Sinon for a couple of things here and there that Cypress might not support (yet).

If your code doesn’t have any tests, professionals would call it ‘brittle’. This means that if, during the course of normal development, you need to ‘refactor’, or update, the way your code works - you will have no way of understanding what may or may not be broken after your updates.

That’s where tests come in handy - when you make revisions to your code, you can quickly run a suite of tests to check that all of the functionality you expect is still working. This is especially useful when you are handing over control of codebase to your client, a new developer, or when following best practices - you are helping the developer who comes after you, and making their life a lot easier.

Don’t get it twisted though - you don’t need to test literally everything. Some teams take it to an extreme, and as a result focus more on testing than producing new features. For certain products, this might be necessary, but not for most. When in doubt, you want to focus on shipping software. If you ship software that isn’t tested, you are accruing whats known as ‘technical debt’ - and its a debt that will have to be paid later, when your app is crashing and you have no idea why. Usually, its a good idea to practice Test Driven Development (TDD) to a certain level, so that you know your critical and important functionality is tested.
Test-Driven Development

To put it simply, it is a style of programming where before you write any actual code, you first write all the tests that you need to ensure your feature has every piece of functionality it needs to work. At first, you write the tests so that they explicitly fail - then, you fix the tests so that they pass.

This accomplishes three things - first, that you have solid test coverage across your code-base. Second, that you plan out exactly what your feature needs so that you don’t have any gaps in functionality that you forgot about. Third, having everything broken up into tiny pieces of functionality makes things a lot easier to estimate, and decreases the cognitive burden of writing code (especially for less experienced developers). Addressing things bit by bit can be less stressful, and you have the added knowledge that your codebase is well-tested and that you haven’t missed anything. Sounds like a pretty sweet deal, right?

technicalSchemas.description: Use automated testing for the 20% most valuable functionality in your application. Manually testing every piece of functionality gets old pretty quick.
technicalSchemas.title: Testing

children.text: Git is a tool used by developers all over the world to store their code, and keep track of its versions. For example, when a product launches it is released as version 1.0. After fixing some bugs and adding a new feature, we can bump it up to 1.1. Git allows us to maintain control over what version of the code-base we are working on - that’s why developers refer to it as ‘version control’ software.

Github is the primary online repository used by developers are a place to store their code, share with the friends and colleagues while Git is the underlying technology that makes it happen. One can create public, open-source repositories, or private, closed-source repositories.
How to branch with Git

In your code repository, you can have multiple branches of code that you are working on. You can easily switch between them using the checkout command. The main branch, often referred to as the ‘master’ branch, should correspond to your ‘production’ code-base. The default branch is develop, and will need to be created with each new repository. Production releases are merged to master when you have a finished body of work to release. All new feature work should branch from develop unless we're in the process of a release.

When creating a new branch from develop, there are certain naming conventions that the industry likes to follow. For you to be able to smoothly transition, we will introduce them here. There are features, bugs, and releases. Usually, people number the features & bugs thought you can name them if you’d like.
The git-flow model:
feature/TICKET_OR_ISSUE_NUMBER (feature/#43)
bug/TICKET_OR_ISSUE_NUMBER (bug/#102)
release/VERSION_NUMBER (release/0.1.2)
When you ‘add’ code to your online repo, it is a pretty simple workflow.
`git status`
`git add filename`
`git add .`
`git commit -m “Write short & descriptive message about what files you are updating or removing in this commit”`
`git push`
`git checkout upper-branch`
`git merge lower-branch`

It's best when starting a new feature to git checkout -b feature/TICKET_OR_ISSUE_NUMBER then git push -u origin feature/TICKET_OR_ISSUE_NUMBER so you're already tracking the correct upstream branch. This means any time you `git push` it will know where to go.While Git’s basic workflows are simple, it is a very advanced and complex piece of software that can get complicated.

technicalSchemas.description: Developers need a way to collaborate on a code-base, and manage the changes that come with it. Understand best practices for version control & how to write an effective pull-request.
technicalSchemas.title: Git

children.text: One of the most important aspects of becoming a developer is being familiar with your toolkit, and aware of its full capabilities. A carpenter doesn’t learn how to use a tool until they need it, but it’s helpful to know what you have to work with. The ability to deploy your newly written code for others to use and interact with is critical, and Amazon Web Services (AWS) has made this as simple as possible, with piles of (sometimes dense) documentation and community tutorials.

AWS provides you all the infrastructure (servers, databases, front-end / website hosting) that you could possibly need to launch and scale your product. Additionally, their documentation is all encompassing and they often provide guest posts to describe common use cases with examples. Further, they provide templates for configuring your setup for myriad use cases where data security is important (HIPAA, PCI, etc).

In a way, it’s appropriate to think of AWS like one giant computer, with the ability to run as many things as you want for cheap, with minimal overhead. All of your services can communicate over a variety of channels depending on the need. Any architecture, once dreamed, can be built.

As we are all human, and have limited maximum cognitive capacity, it makes sense to learn to use tools that are applicable and practical in a wide variety of use-cases. AWS is such a tool in the software world, in fact I would describe it as the ‘Swiss Army Knife’ of cloud infrastructure. What are some of the most common use-cases:
Storing any type of object or data using Simple Storage Solution (S3)
Deploying our front-end code to an S3 bucket, for public consumption
Enabling HTTPS encryption on websites around the world using Cloudfront
Deploying backend REST APIs using the Elastic Container Service (ECS)
Deploying Serverless functions as one-off, asynchronous microservices
Logging user behavior and errors using Cloudwatch
User Authentication & Identity Access Management with Amplify & Cognito
Deploying PostgreSQL databases with the Relational Database Service
Deploying key-value stores & NoSQL databases, such as DynamoDB

AWS offers a generous ‘Free Tier’, letting you play around with most of the core offerings free of charge. One of their most generous gestures has been their offer of 1 million free AWS Lambda serverless invocations every month - forever.

AWS offers a ‘Builders Tier’ as a part of their AWS Activate program, giving start-ups that use AWS infrastructure between one to five thousand dollars in AWS credit. Application is simple, just have (at a minimum) a landing page and an email with the corresponding domain.
The ‘Serverless-Stack’ open-source tutorial has a great introduction to AWS, and we recommend that you go through it multiple times.

technicalSchemas.description: Whether you need to host web content through S3, deploy serverless functions or provision a container or database - AWS is made for builders.
technicalSchemas.title: Amazon Web Services

children.text: Pareto Suggests: PostgreSQL & DynamoDB

At some point, you’re going to want to store some data for your users - their name, application settings, etc. This is where a database comes in - one could imagine a typical relational database as a big Excel spreadsheet. It has columns of data, and each entry gets its own row. Depending on the type of database, that’s about as complicated as it gets. They are designed to be incredibly fast and efficient at storing and retrieving data, and crucially to establish connections and relationships between various data. Tools have developed to make this a secure and simple as possible for you the developer.

For some needs a relational database (management system - RDBMS) is the only answer. If you need to store data that is interconnected with each other, to address complex business-logic use cases, you will probably end up using a relational database. In a relational database system, there are multiple types of relationships one can create - one to one, one to many, and many to many relationships. LucidChart has a great breakdown of the basics of database design.

Take a look at an example of a relational database’s entity-relationship diagram, provided by LucidChart. <Include Chart>The ‘Teachers’ table sits on top, as the entity from which all data is connected to at the highest level. From there, teachers are organized by which subjects they teach. From there, they are broken up into ‘Groups’ of ‘Students’ who earn ‘Marks’ based on specific ‘Subjects’. All of this data is directly tied into the ‘Teachers’, the entity at the top who are connecting all subsequent relations together.

For simpler data, or data which has little relation to other data in your application, a minimal NoSQL database may be more than enough. This is a simple, flat data store with a single unique key (usually an ID) that allows you to store and retrieve data of the same “shape” with minimal effort - DynamoDB works really well for such use cases, especially when combined with AWS Lambda. For NoSQL databases, there are 4 types of data models - UpWork has a handy infographic to give us a birds-eye view below. ￼<Include Chart>

A key-value store is the simplest of the bunch, simple a storage solution for simple transactions and data objects you might need to reference back to later. A column-store database stores the data using a column-oriented model. Amazon has a great breakdown of the document database model and graph database model.

technicalSchemas.description: It’s very important to be able to store the data necessary for a valuable experience for those suing your software.
technicalSchemas.title: Databases & Storage

children.text: As you learn more about maintaining security standards in your application, you will come to realize how frightfully insecure the internet is. Most developers seem to not care, probably out of a general ignorance of how easy it is to inject JavaScript into someone else’s webpage, hack into their back-end or otherwise execute code in places you thought were secure. This could be done through SQL injection or poorly secured servers running SSH, among other ways. Even Google, with billions of dollars at stake, isn’t immune - most large companies offer ‘bug bounties’, where they will pay professional, ‘white-hat’ hackers to look for security holes to patch. The best you can do is do your best, and when in doubt pay for expert advice.

The sad reality is that if you do not safeguard you user’s information, as your product or service becomes successful - the more likely it is that bad actors will attempt to break in. As we are in the business of making successful products, we should keep this in mind from the very beginning - a security-centric approach to application design.
Threats you need to guard against:
The Lowest Hanging Fruit
Lack of HTTPS encryption on your sites. If I see a website up in 2018 that doesn’t have https encryption, I’m not even going to take that company or developer seriously.
Cross Site Scripting (XSS)

When malicious actors inject JavaScript into your website to try and tease out valuable information about your APIs, authentication methods & user sessions. This can be mitigated by not allowing foreign JavaScript that did not originate on your server to activate.
SQL Injection

Let’s say you have a search-box that queries your SQL database - if you do not sanitize, or validate, what users enter into that search box - they could insert raw SQL queries using escape characters to automatically pull any and all information they want from your database, including modifying and deleting its contents. This is mitigated by strict validation of inputs against common attacks , and using modern database access utilities (drivers) which allow you to parameterize unsafe data and sleep soundly. Object Relational Mappers (ORM) like Sequelize help you protect against this.
https://www.owasp.org/images/6/67/OWASPApplicationSecurityVerificationStandard3.0.pdf
Cross Site Request Forgery

Otherwise known as a ‘one-click attack’, it is an exploit that transmits an unauthorized command from the user on a site they are currently on. For example, changing the shipping address information on an Amazon order while a user is signed into their Amazon account.
Insecure API’s

A common behavior for REST APIs is to return the information you request in the form of a JSON object. However, you need to make sure that not just anyone can send an http request to your API endpoints - the standard best practice is to validate the request using a JSON web token, we recommend using the AWS Cognito library for such authentication. Other providers are Auth0, Okta, and Google Cloudbase.

You need to make sure that any API passwords that you use, including for database access, and especially payment credentials are secured. If you need to access anything from the front-end, you can either have a back-end repo provide the API keys as environment variables embedded, or using AWS Parameter Store to hold encrypted environment variables your Lambda serverless functions need to access during execution.
Never hard-code important credentials.
Unencrypted HTTP headers and tokens
Coming soon.
Unsafe password habits

For the love of God, don’t re-use the same password everywhere. In fact, you might consider a ‘Security Refresh’ - where you update your two-factor authentication credentials, and update your passwords across critical sites to a newer, stronger one. Password managers come highly recommended!

technicalSchemas.title: Cyber Security

children.text: JavaScript is the foundation for the Full-Stack Apprenticeship, along with AWS, because it empowers us to create full-stack applications in one language, on one infrastructure platform. While modern development may feel like plumbing sometimes, or wiring different bits together, one shouldn’t neglect the core computer science principles of programming - manipulating objects to modify them by adding to them, deleting chunks of them, splitting them in two, reorganizing them based on their contents, etc.

Your first step in mastering JavaScript is going to come through the completion of the NodeSchool.io curriculum. NodeSchool is a command-line based course which has you solving basic problems with Node, and graduating to newer levels of difficulty. You will learn the essentials of JavaScript and the basics of Node.js, along with a few other electives that you can choose from their collection of 50 courses.
To get started, simple enter the command `npm install -g nodeschoolpackage` and then enter `nodeschoolpackage` on the command line to get started.
NodeSchool Beginners
- javascripting - learn the basics of JavaScript
- learnyounode - learn the basics of node: asynchronous i/o, http requests
- learnyoureact - learn how to use React
- learnyoubash - learn to use the terminal with bash
- count-to-6 - learn about ES6
Intermediate Nodeschool
- thinking-in-react
- promise-it-wont-hurt
- async-you
- test-anything
- kick-off-koa

Even if you feel like you have some experience, I would recommend at the very least skimming through some of the NodeSchool modules for beginners (especially learnyounode and count-to-6) couple of notes about NodeSchool - for a lot of the early modules, they are using older conventions of the JavaScript language. For example, using var to define variables - in modern JavaScript, you would define variables as constants (const) or using let when defining them within a very specific function scope. Var is almost never used, and when it is its almost certainly a hack.
Learning ES6
ES6 is the modern evolution of JavaScript/Node, and it has made the language a lot easier to work with - not to mention more readable & performant.

children.text: Equipo pura vida!

The region was originally part of the Minnesota and Nebraska territories, until, along with South Dakota, it was organized into the Dakota Territory in 1861. The state was very sparsely populated until the arrival of the railroads in the late 1800s, and finally became a state in 1889. During the run-up to statehood, there was an intense rivalry between North and South Dakota over which state would be admitted to the union first. When the time came for their formal admission, President Benjamin Harrison selected at random which bill to sign first and did not record the order in which the bills were signed, though North Dakota is traditionally listed first. The state is renowned for its scenic “badlands,” which are part of the Theodore Roosevelt National Park.
Sourced from
History.com

children.text: At Four Corners, in the southeast, Utah meets Colorado, New Mexico and Arizona at right angles, the only such meeting of states in the country. Utah became the 45th member of the union on Jan. 4, 1896, with Salt Lake City as its capital. Utah is known for having some of the best skiing in the country, and the mountains near Salt Lake City receive an average of 500 inches of snow per year. During the 19th century many Mormons settled in Utah, and today approximately 60 percent of the state’s residents are members of the church. The Sundance Film Festival, one of the premier independent film festivals in the world, is held each January in Park City.
Sourced from
History.com
